data.name: Alpha Code
data.description:
<font color="red">Alice</font> and <font color="yellow">Bob</font> need to send secret messages to each other and are discussing ways to encode their messages:

> <font color="red">Alice</font>: “Let’s just use a very simple code: We’ll assign ‘A’ the code word 1, ‘B’ will be 2, and so on down to ‘Z’ being assigned 26.”

> <font color="yellow">Bob</font>: “That’s a stupid code, Alice. Suppose I send you the word ‘BEAN’ encoded as 25114. You could decode that in many different ways!”

> <font color="red">Alice</font>: “Sure you could, but what words would you get? Other than `BEAN`, you’d get `BEAAD`, `YAAD`, `YAN`, `YKD` and `BEKD`. I think you would be able to figure out the correct decoding. And why would you send me the word `BEAN` anyway?”

> <font color="yellow">Bob</font>: “OK, maybe that’s a bad example, but I bet you that if you got a string of length 5000 there would be tons of different decodings and with that many you would find at least two different ones that would make sense.”

> <font color="red">Alice</font>: “How many different decodings?”

> <font color="yellow">Bob</font>: “Jillions!”

For some reason, <font color="red">Alice</font> is still unconvinced by <font color="yellow">Bob’s</font> argument, so she requires a program that will determine how many decodings there can be for a given string using her code.
